Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Elucidating the Role of SYP132A during Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Symbiosis in Oryza Sativa
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants often recruit soil microbes in order to enhance nutrient availability and absorption by an assortment of mechanisms. Nitrogen-fixing (NF) symbiosis and arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) symbiosis are two important examples. NF symbiosis has major growth effects on the crops that can form this relationship such as soybean, common bean, pea, peanuts, alfalfa, etc., while AM symbiosis can do the same for many crops that form this symbiosis such as maize and rice. Rice (Oryza sativa), specifically, can have a significant grain yield increase when inoculated with mycorrhizal fungi because of the enhanced nutrient uptake. This can be especially important in parts of the world that rely on this particular crop for the majority of its calories. This award supports research to investigate the role of the SYP132A gene in rice (Oryza sativa) by defining the mycorrhizal phenotype of rice SYP132A mutants.The research could ultimately shed light on a fundamental process in rice (AM symbiosis) that has the potential to greatly increase yield if optimized. The research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Ertao Wang, an expert in AM symbiosis in rice, at the Institute of Plant Physiology and Ecology in Shanghai, China.

The nitrogen-fixing (NF) symbiotic pathway in plants evolved from the arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) symbiotic pathway, and therefore the molecular mechanisms share many common elements. Protein trafficking from the plant to the bacteria during NF symbiosis has been shown to be indispensable, but protein trafficking during AM symbiosis is most likely important as well. For this proposed project, I will study the role of a syntaxin gene (SYP132A) in mycorrhizal symbiosis. This gene was previously identified to have a role in NF symbiosis in M. truncatula, namely, it specifically marks the membrane surrounding the intracellular bacteria for targeted protein delivery. I will investigate the function of SYP132A by characterizing the mycorrhizal phenotype of rice T-DNA mutant lines. My hypothesis is that this protein marks the membrane that separates host from the fungus within plant cells. This study will provide evidence that the function of SYP132A is universal and spans multiple host and microbial species. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most land plants form a symbiotic relationship with arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungi. These fungi enter plant root cells and deliver nutrients from the surrounding soil, such as phosphorous and nitrogen, that are normally difficult for the plant obtain by itself. Understanding what is required for this relationship to develop and be maintained is important for understanding plant nutrition.

Another plant-microbe symbiosis is nitrogen-fixing (NF) symbiosis, where soil bacteria enter the roots of certain plant species (mostly legumes) and turn atmospheric nitrogen into a form that the plant can use. The ability of these plants to form NF symbiosis evolved from the AM symbiosis pathway. Medicago truncatula is the model plant for studying NF symbiosis; it also forms AM symbiosis, which makes it a convenient tool for identifying genes that are involved in one symbiosis or in both.

This project investigated seven M. truncatula mutant lines that were known to have defects in the pathway involved in NF symbiosis. These mutants all had an underdeveloped symbiosis, meaning that the bacteria were getting into the plant root, but not fixing any nitrogen. We wanted to understand if the unidentified genes that caused NF symbiosis to be defective also played a role in AM symbiosis. If the mutants were not able to form fully functional AM symbiosis, then we could conclude that the gene was involved in both symbioses. On the other hand, if the mutants did not have any issues forming AM symbiosis, then the gene is probably only involved in NF symbiosis. Either outcome would give us information about the gene and what type of role it could play in the symbiotic pathway.

We inoculated seven mutant lines and one non-mutant (wild-type) line of plants with AM fungi. We allowed the symbiosis to form for six weeks in media with very low nutrients. After six weeks, we harvested the plants, stained the roots and determined the percent colonization of the roots by the fungus.

We found two mutant M. truncatula lines (named mutant #4 and mutant #5) that had a greater percent colonization by the fungus (Figure 1); however, we did not find any mutants that had a lower percent colonization compared to the wild-type. This was surprising because we predicted that some mutants would have less colonization, not more. The two mutant lines that had greater colonization are intriguing because they could have greater colonization for several reasons. The fungal relationship could be under-developed, leading to a decrease in its effectiveness. In this case, the plant may be trying to recruit more fungus to make up for not receiving enough nutrients. Another possibility is that the fungal structures within the plant cells are aging quickly and becoming non-functional early. This would indicate that the symbiotic partnership is not maintained. Finally, the plant may be recruiting the fungus because it senses a deficiency in nitrogen. Normally, the plant would obtain nitrogen from the bacteria with the roots, but these mutants cannot because they have a mutation in a gene involved in NF symbiosis. Therefore, the plants could be attempting to get their nitrogen from the fungus instead. If this were the case, then we would expect all of the mutants to have significantly higher percent colonization, which we do not see. Therefore, it may be interesting to try and elucidate the feedback mechanisms behind the lack of nitrogen and the increase in fungal recruitment.

In order to determine why these two mutant lines have increased fungal colonization, more experiments should be carried out. If we can measure how effective the symbiosis is, we can determine if the fungal structures are developed and maintained properly.
